channel.title: Decibels
channel.description:
Hey Mopar,
I'm wondering what is the loudest Decibel the human ear can listen to without any harm? It is a car stereo?
Thanks.

item.title: Decibels
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Explains it all.

Read full topic

item.title: Decibels
item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

My car is around 150 db and my friend’s is right around 160 (He’s a show car for a big company and he has drained so much money into this shit.

I’m partially deaf in my left ear but my friend is fine and his shit compares to a plane taking off.

Read full topic

item.title: Decibels
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote="(Anthony), post:10, topic:460247"][quote author=Niall link=topic=563168.msg4106220#msg4106220 date=1348010992]

I have tinnitus, it didn’t get worse until my second music festival, the volume was so loud you could feel the vibrations in your chest and body

if you value your hearing don’t listen to LOUD music for extended periods of time

Or y’know, get decent earplugs???

my tinnitus is already distracting enough for me to not bother about ear protection

I might get some if I ever do some serious festival going but the one off here and there… eh
[/quote]
yo m8 firefly is never coming back[/quote]

I know

Read full topic

item.title: Decibels
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Up to 110 db(A) for a short period. (With ear protection) (I’m note sure about the accurate number, but a couple of minutes at maximum.)
Up to 85 db(A) for a longer period. (8 hours) (Without ear protection)

This is based on Norwegian regulations for noise in the workplace.

To scare you a bit, for ever 10 point increase in decibel, the intensity increase by ten.
110 db is 1000 times more powerful than 80 decibel.

Read full topic
